dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE COUNTRY HOUSE
dialogues.text: An ancient house, standing lonely in the middle of a  deserted landscape in Northern Germany; lying there like sleeping giant under the starry sky. But something seems strange: All of the windows and doors have been nailed shut. Text chart: "1976" The headlights of a car pierce the darkness.  A car halts in the yard.  Three MEN step out.  One of them is wearing police uniform.  The men switch on their flashlights and  look around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long has the house already  been like this? KARL LINDNER, a keen police officer in his late thirties, approaches the entrance door.  He speaks in a calm, hoars voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No idea. I haven't seen them in  weeks.  Lindner makes himself a picture of the situation. He rings the doorbell.  Nothing stirs inside the house.   Then, he tries to get a look inside through one of the  nailed-shut windows. Through the cracks, he can barely make out a faint  pulsating light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't seen them in weeks. The three men exchange looks.   With a heavy heart, Lindner makes his decision:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're going in. The third man fetches a crowbar and prepares to open the  door with it.

dialogues.speaker: ENTRANCE AREA / COUNTRY HOUSE
dialogues.text: The house door breaks open with a loud crack. On the floor below the mail slot, there are piles of mail and unread newspapers which the door pushes out of the wa as it opens. The three men cautiously enter.  They look around.  The  hallway is as dark as night.  Lindner tries the light  switch - nothing.  The only light comes from a TV-set  running in the living room.

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: The three of them enter the living room.  Disgusted, the  first man holds a handkerchief to his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pooh, what a stench... There is a massive armchair in the center of the room, in front of the television. - There seems to be someone  sitting in it.  In the darkness we cannot recognize who i is. Lindner carefully steps closer. The second man stops in front of a large, dark stain on t wall.  He touches it, draws back his hand and inspects it - blood. Lindner slowly walks around the armchair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My God... Marlene...! During the next flicker of light from the television, we  recognize the corpse of a woman around forty years of age Suddenly, Lindner hears something behind him - breathing! He turns around. Indeed, hidden in the semi-darkness, there is the shadow a figure squatting on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank... Hell, what happened in  here? Lindner carefully approaches the figure. It is a man, FRANK KOSINSKI.  He looks scrawny, all skin  and bones, with a pale and hollow face. He doesn't pay the least attention to Lindner.  Mesmerize he just stares at the dead woman in the armchair. The "first man" follows the direction the man is looking and takes a careful look at the dead woman.  Something  seems to be irritating him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now that's really odd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?  What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd say she drowned... Lindner leans over to the lethargic man in the shadows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank...!? He gently touches his shoulder.  At the same moment,  Kosinski seems to snap out of it. He begins to scream in wild panic - loud, heartrending!

dialogues.speaker: TITLE SEQUENCE
dialogues.text: A photo montage of corpses, preserved in the swamps over  hundreds and thousands of years: children, old people,  warriors, farmers with hair stained red from the humin  acid, bony extremities and shriveled faces with skin that resembles an ancient landscape ...

dialogues.speaker: LANDSCAPE OF SWAMPS IN NORTHERN GERMANY
dialogues.text: The structures of the corpses' skin fade into pictures of vast landscape of heaths, forests and moors. An expensive offroad vehicle is leading a sports car alon a deserted country road.  It's a wonderful late-summer's  day.  The two cars take a bend...

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE COUNTRY HOUSE
dialogues.text: ... into the driveway of the same old house.  It lies  peacefully in the afternoon sun.  The gravel crunches  underneath the tires. A large moving truck is already parked outside. Title chart: "23 years later"

dialogues.speaker: OFFROAD VEHICLE
dialogues.text: Driving the Jeep is ELLEN STRAUB, an attractive, self- assured woman of approx. 30 years. Asleep on the passenger's seat beside her is her husband  MARTIN, who in no way resembles the clichГ© of the  successful author - he has a rather boyish charisma and i a bit too attractive. Ellen stops the car and takes out some house keys.  She  holds them right up to her sleeping husband's ear.  Then, she shakes them.  They tinkle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (playful)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, we have arrived at your  residence. Martin blinks and takes the keys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, James. The two of them step out of the car.

dialogues.speaker: IN FRONT OF THE HOUSE
dialogues.text: Also getting out of their sports car are PAUL - a dynamic looking man in his mid-forties - and his wife CLAUDIA.   Despite their careful choice of casual dress, they still  look like the epitome of snobbish city people. They take a look around.  Time has left it's marks on the old house:  Like an enchanted castle, it is camouflaged i waist-high grass and wildly ranking shrubs. Paul and Claudia exchange skeptic looks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, look here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentlemen: The  "Straub country-residence".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It looks more like the "Straub  ruins".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome to the far end of the  world. Ellen contradicts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lap of nature.  Where's  your famous optimism? Two REMOVAL MEN climb out of the truck.  One of them is  still chewing on his lunch. He points at his watch as he addresses Martin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lunch break is 'til one  o'clock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sarcastic)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, take your time. (to Ellen)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They get a lunch break before  they even start working.   Cool job. Laughing, the four of them enter the house.

dialogues.speaker: ENTRANCE AREA
dialogues.text: They step into the entrance area.  The golden sunlight  shines in stripes through the shutters.  The house is old monumental.  One senses the centuries.  A staircase leads upstairs, the rooms on the first floor  are the kitchen and living room.  A heavy wooden door ope to the cellar stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The country residence offers  everything the doctor ordered  for a stressed author needs:  fresh air, clean water and -  most of all - absolute peace  and quiet. Paul walks upstairs.  The staircase creaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This wood is pretty decayed.   Hope I don't land a floor  lower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Although it would give you a  perfect opportunity to visit  our new wine cellar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How old is this shack, anyway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four hundred years.  Come on,  I'll give you a tour of the  museum... (blinking an eye at Martin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: and Paul) ...while our husbands already  get to work.

dialogues.speaker: IN FRONT OF THE HOUSE
dialogues.text: Martin and Paul are lugging a heavy desk out of the truck As opposed to the two removal men, they are really workin hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn, this thing is heavy.  Where do you want to have it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tenth floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very funny.

dialogues.speaker: STUDY
dialogues.text: Sweating, Martin and Paul are trying to push the desk  through the narrow door to the study.  They are doing a  pretty awkward job of it. Martin's hand brushes the door frame - a splinter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit! Martin draws back his hand.  He's hurt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter? Martin presses a handkerchief on the wound and has a clos look at the door frame. It is totally splintered, as if someone had forcefully  broken the door open!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at this.  The lock is  totally demolished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess someone lost their key.   You did get your tetanus shots,  I hope? Martin is still looking at the broken lock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, seriously: It is  strange, isn't it? Paul puts it off.  Only now does he have a better look  around the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what if it is.  There hasn't  been anyone in this house for  at least ten years. The study is covered with dust, the walls are stained and full of cobwebs - blind, high arched windows.  Single  pieces of furniture that the previous owner left behind i this spacious room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty-three, to be exact.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wonder how you guys figure on  renovating this whole place.   You can afford to spend some  money.  If I was you, I'd spare  myself all the hard work.   Besides, didn't you want to  start writing again? Martin suddenly seems lost in thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah sure, I will. Give me a  little more time. Paul gives him a downcast look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you throw away your career,  that won't change anything  either.  Now don't get me  wrong, but I'm telling you this  as your friend:  Your last  books were awful.  The  publishing house isn't even  sure whether to extend your  contract. Martin takes the handkerchief from his wound and looks at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care about my career  right now, Paul.  Ellen and I  need to get our minds on other  things, first.  After  everything we've been through.

dialogues.speaker: KITCHEN
dialogues.text: Ellen is dragging a moving carton full of dishes into the kitchen.  It seems to be very heavy.  Claudia hooks up a  radio and switches it on.  We hear a cheerful oldie (Life could be a Dream).   The song seems to bring back memories to Ellen:  She star at the radio. (Transformation from radio to:)

dialogues.speaker: DINING ROOM OF CITY APARTMENT
dialogues.text: Flashback: Ellen, Martin and their son THOMAS (8 years old) are join at the breakfast table.  The radio is on - it's playing t same tune. The little boy is totally absorbed with his Game-boy. Martin sets a bowl of cornflakes and fresh fruit on the  table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here, partner:  A breakfast for  champions. The little boy rolls his eyes and turns back to his Game- boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't right now!  I'm about  to break the high-score! Ellen gets into the discussion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do that.  But first, eat  your breakfast, Tommi. Now, Thomas reacts.  He puts the Game-boy on the table.   He continues the game with one hand, while he obediently  shovels the breakfast cereal into his mouth with the othe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goes to show again who's in  command around here. Martin gives Ellen a playful pat on the behind and kisses her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (joking)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes I get the feeling you  only love me for my body. Martin grins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, say it.  You know... Martin seems to know exactly what Ellen wants to hear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no, not again.  I just said  it for you last week. For a moment, the two of them stop paying attention to  their son.  Suddenly, Thomas grabs his throat.  He  swallowed wrong.  He chokes without making a sound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say it anyway.  Come on, how  much do you love me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quotes)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "With you, my life began  and with you shall it end..." Ellen gives him her most beautiful smile.  Martin respond with a short kiss.   At the same time, they hear the Game-boy fall to the floo It immediately draws their attention to Thomas. The little boy is desperately gasping for air.  His face already starting to turn blue. Martin runs to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tommi, what's the matter? He pats Thomas on the back, attempting to clear his throa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?  What's wrong with  him? Thomas coughs, choking, but he can't get his throat clear Martin recognizes the situation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yells)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is serious!  Quick, call  emergency! Ellen hurries to the phone. Martin realizes that hitting Thomas' back is not doing an good.  He uses his finger to try to get the swallowed pie out of his son's throat. For Thomas, it is a battle against death. Ellen has gotten through to the emergency line.  She spea into the phone with distress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Straub.  You have to  come, fast!  My son, he  swallowed something... Quick,  he's choking to death... Martin's attempts at helping his son remain futile.  Thom is beginning to lose conscience. Martin sweeps the table free of dishes in a single move a lays the little boy down flat.  He reaches for a sharp  fruit knife. Ellen comes running.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing? Martin holds the tip of the knife to the boy's throat.   It's not easy, since his son is wildly kicking around  himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to cut his windpipe...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (horrified)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not a doctor, you'll  hurt him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (screams)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What else should I do, damn it,  he's dying! Again, Martin prepares to cut - he holds the knife to the larynx.  The boy's movements grow weaker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too high, you're way too far  up... you have to cut here... She points at the spot below the larynx while holding her little son tight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ellen, move aside...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh God, Tommi... Martin prepares to cut, but he can't - his trembling hand refuses to move.  Endless seconds pass.  The voices blur, like in a dream.  The music playing on the radio seems to become louder and louder (Life could be a Dream).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter?  Come on,  cut... Martin looks up at his wife.  He can't do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ellen!

dialogues.speaker: KITCHEN
dialogues.text: Ellen starts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ellen, are you alright? Claudia has already started unpacking the carton. Ellen quickly switches the radio off.  She tries to act a if nothing happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm fine.  I was just  distracted for a moment. Claudia notices how upset her friend is and wants to put  her arm around Ellen's shoulder.   But just then, the removal men push their way past them  with a cupboard. Claudia drops the issue with a look of sympathy.

dialogues.speaker: IN FRONT OF THE HOUSE
dialogues.text: The old house is resting peacefully in the sunset.  The  last rays of sunlight paint the horizon orange.  Warm lig shines out through the windows of the house.

dialogues.speaker: KITCHEN
dialogues.text: The four friends are joined at the dinner table,   surrounded by packing cartons.  Their shadows are  silhouetted outside the large window.  Behind them lie th vast, lonely moors. Martin opens himself a beer, raises it for a toast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To our hard-working wives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't rejoice too soon.  The  bill is already on it's way. They toast with their bottles.  Ellen takes herself a  cigarette.  Martin notices it with disapproval.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I still can't picture it: The  two of you as country folk.   I'm telling you, in six weeks  you'll be back in the city.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold it right there!  I hate to  play the big boss, but as  Martin's publisher I can only  say:  Make the best of the  peace and quiet, the fresh air  and all that - and write a new  masterpiece! Ellen gives Martin a skeptical look - the moment of silen is almost too long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First things first.  Now it's  our turn - just the two of us. Martin's hand wanders over to Ellen's.  She reacts a bit  hesitantly at first, but then they hold each other tight.

dialogues.speaker: BATHROOM
dialogues.text: Ellen is taking a shower, washing off the dirt from a har day's work. The bathroom fills with steam. Ellen turns off the water faucet and steps out of the  shower cabin.  She reaches for a towel and wraps it aroun herself. Something catches her eye in the fogged-up mirror.   There is a number, as if someone had used a finger to wri it into the moisture: "7". She wipes the mirror clean and looks at it.

dialogues.speaker: IN FRONT OF THE HOUSE
dialogues.text: The following day: A warm late-summer's morning.  The house stands lonely in the rays of the rising sun.  Occasional dew drops glitter in the grass.

dialogues.speaker: BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Ellen is asleep in her bed, despite the sun shining right in her face. Martin enters the room with a tray loaded with breakfast  delicacies.  He holds it under Ellen's nose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (acting gallant)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wake up, wake up, it's break  of day."  Paul and Claudia have  already left, you sleepyhead. Ellen hides under her blanket.  Martin sets down the tray

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right.  Forget about  getting up.  We'll have  breakfast in bed. Ellen resurfaces with a grin.  She is still sleepy. Martin jumps into bed and crawls under the blanket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How romantic! He playfully burrows around under the blanket, making sil grunting sounds. Ellen giggles.  Suddenly, Martin sticks his head out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a grunting voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll never get away from me! He grabs her and pulls her under the blanket.  Ellen  screams, and laughs.

dialogues.speaker: STUDY
dialogues.text: Martin is working at his computer.  Everything is still s up a bit provisionally.  Only Martin's novels have alread been sorted into a shelf, with 10 copies of "Cherry-red  Tears" in front. He is trying to write, but by the look on his face and hi hesitant typing, we can tell that it's obviously not goin so well. Ellen carefully approaches him from behind, hugs him and  gives him a kiss on the cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, how does it feel to be  kissed by two women?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They say it's fantastic.  At  least that's what I read in a  men's magazine.  So who are the  two lucky ones?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me and the muse, of course.   How is your book coming along? He grins and takes her in his arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, the muse... we're still  having our differences.  You  know how it is with women.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well then, I guess I'd better  leave the two of you alone.   But don't forget... Martin finishes her thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... we wanted to take some time  out for ourselves.  I know.   And I'll only work a little  while, I promise. Just as Ellen prepares to leave, she catches sight of an  old photograph lying on top of one of the cartons.  She  picks it up and takes the dust off of it. Under the dust, she finds an old black and white picture a couple with very earnest looks.  The retouched, pitch- black eyes give the photo a somewhat eerie touch. All of a sudden, unexpectedly, the man on the photo turns his head. His dead eyes look straight at Ellen! Startled, she drops the picture to the floor. Martin spins around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter? Ellen hesitantly picks up the picture and looks at it  again.  It was only her imagination.  It is a normal, old black and white photo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (irritated)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, nothing.  Where did this  picture come from? Martin turns back to his work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I found it here.  It's kind of  creepy, don't you think? Ellen makes a face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  It is, kind of. She puts the picture back and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Ellen comes out of the kitchen and walks into the dark  living room.  She is carrying some sandwiches on a tray. The room is only lit by the flickering of the television  set.  A spooky atmosphere. In front of the TV is a large, old armchair (the same one from the opening sequence!).  Ellen frowns.  She slowly  walks closer to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin? Suddenly, Martin's voice comes from behind the armchair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn! Martin pounds his flat hand against the television.  The  screen shows no image, only snow. Ellen sets down the tray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of a horrible thing  is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It still worked in town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean the armchair!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, that was upstairs.  A real  antiquity!  I think it's great. Ellen instinctively feels appalled by the old piece of  furniture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Martin is still fighting with the TV-set, trying to find channel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe the antenna's broken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're probably lucky that we  even have running water and  electricity!  Damned box! He hits the TV with his fist. Suddenly, everything is dark!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey... the fuse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, damnit! He looks for a flashlight and switches it on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know where fuse box is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the cellar, I think.   Wait, I'll take care of it. He leaves the room.

dialogues.speaker: CELLAR
dialogues.text: Martin opens the fuse box and shines inside with his  flashlight:  A moldy mess of half-corroded wires leading  into various ancient switches.  The entire construction  makes a dangerous impression.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (talking to himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, look at that... The cellar seems even older than the house.  It is a larg cold sandstone catacomb.  Several pillars support the  ceiling.  The walls are clammy and cold. Martin is standing in the darkness.  Something approaches him from behind - slowly, threateningly. Martin is looking for the blown fuse. The thing comes closer.  Finally, it grabs him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boo! Martin spins around, startled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ! Ellen laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted to know what's taking  you so long.  You've been down  here forever.   (looks around, shivering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It sure is cold down here.  We  certainly won't be needing a  freezer. She catches sight of an old shelf loaded with all kinds o strange old junk.  The shelf looks old and rickety.  Elle shakes at it, testing its stability.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll sure be sorting a bunch  of this stuff out. Martin points to the fuse box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at this!  We'll have to  fix the whole wiring.  This  stuff is dangerous as hell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll call for someone from  town first thing in the  morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you crazy?  That costs a  fortune!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have a better idea?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll do it myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My father was an electrician.   Already forgot that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My father was a pilot.  And do  I know how to fly? There's a lot more Ellen would like to say about this, bu she contends herself with a meaningful look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just do me a favor and don't  get yourself roasted! Martin fumbles with one of the bigger switches, finally  flips it to the other side.  Click!  The catacomb is lit: lonely 40-Watt lamp dangling from the ceiling casts a dim light. Martin gives Ellen a triumphant smile.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE OF THE HOUSE DOOR
dialogues.text: Ellen is leaning against the door frame, dreamily gazing  into the night.  She is smoking a joint. Martin steps up from behind and takes the hand-rolled  "cigarette" out of her hand with a swift move.  He tosses it away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, flower child, the sixties  are over.  And this stuff is  hazardous to your health.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, daddy. She gives him a hasty kiss and walks to the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if you won't let me smoke  grass, then at least I'll go  get myself some cigarettes.  Ellen gets in the car and takes off. Martin contemplatively watches her go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That stuff is gonna end up  killing you.

dialogues.speaker: COUNTRY ROAD / INSIDE CAR
dialogues.text: Ellen is behind the steering wheel.  She lights up a  cigarette as she drives down a lonely road.  There is a  small bridge in the distance. Ellen slows down.  She glances at a road sign. Suddenly, her eyes widen.  She takes a second look. The road sign clearly reads:  "You have 6 days to live" The shock hits her like a fist. It takes her a moment to react.  Then, she slams her foot on the brake pedal. The car halts with screeching tires.  Ellen shifts into  reverse gear and drives back.  She stops by the sign. She reads: "Max. 6 t. Agricultural vehicles pass" - a  perfectly normal sign. Ellen is confused.  How creepy.  She continues on her way feeling a bit sick to the stomach.

dialogues.speaker: IN FRONT OF THE HOUSE
dialogues.text: Ellen parks in front of the house and steps out of the ca She looks worn-out. Martin has piled up all of the old furniture from the  house.  Ellen walks over to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Making our very own solstice  fire. A match lights up.  The stacked furniture quickly catches fire. Only now does Martin notice the state his wife is in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is everything alright?  Aren't  you feeling well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just had a really strange  experience. Martin gives her a questioning look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On an ordinary traffic sign, I  read... Ellen interrupts her sentence.  She's just too embarrasse to say it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, nothing.  I guess I just  still haven't recovered as well  as I try to make everyone  believe. Martin puts his arm around her and holds her close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I should talk to Dr. Roth  about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, take your time.  You know  time heals better than any  shrink ever can. Arm in arm, Ellen and Martin stand by the burning pile of furniture, staring into the fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a funny feeling.  Do you  think we'll get over all that's  happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We just have to make a new  beginning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cherry-red Tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cherry-red Tears, your first  book.  I read it at least nine  times.  And then I found out  you were going to attend some  kind of book fair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not a book fair.  I was signing  autographs in a department  store.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was so excited about meeting  you.  Again and again, I kept  getting in the back of the line  so I could be the last to talk  to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And two months later, we got  married.  And all because of  one sentence: (quotes)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "With you, my life began  and with you shall it end..." This sentence strikes a chord within Ellen.  It hardens h heart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't say that.  Please. A short moment of silence.  Ellen's eyes well up with  tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I miss Tommi so much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So do I, believe me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you really think anything  can ever be like it was before?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe different.  I don't know,  Ellen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we stand a chance at all,  it's only by sticking together. Martin gives her a tender kiss.  The fire casts a warming shine on the two of them and the old house - in the  loneliness of the moors.

dialogues.speaker: KITCHEN
dialogues.text: Ellen is wearing a paint-stained flannel shirt. She is bu painting the kitchen walls. The RADIO is playing in the background.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "... a very special day today.   Exceptionally hot, even for  this time of year.  And all the  windows in my studio are  already wide open..." Ellen isn't paying much attention to the radio.  Suddenly the tone of the radiobroadcaster's voice gets a more  penetrating touch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the way, Ellen:  You have five days left to  live. Ellen freezes.  She turns pale. Then suddenly, a noise - someone is knocking on the windo Ellen spins around and, startled, tips over a bowl.  It  smashes on the floor. Standing by the open window is Karl Lindner, a total  stranger to Ellen. Obviously, he is much older now.  His face is caved in, h hair gray.  However, his pleasant demeanor has stayed the same. He realizes that he's startled her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, sorry.  I didn't mean to  scare you. For a moment, Ellen is at a loss for words.  She looks ba to the radio, where the normal program is being continued

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "... and matching today's  weather it's time for some more  of the hottest music of the  North..." Ellen turns the radio off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.  Can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does this dog here belong to  you? Sitting next to him is a large mixed-breed with friendly  eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I've never seen him before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, I saw him sitting  outside your gate...  Oh, I'm  sorry, I'm forgetting my  manners again!  I haven't even  introduced myself yet.  Hi, my  name's Lindner.  Karl Lindner. He offers her his hand through the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ellen Straub.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a pleasure.  You're from  the city, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I look like it that much?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Village gossip.  You're a real  attraction here. Ellen is still shook up by the radio announcement, but  nevertheless tries to hold up a conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're from around here, aren't  you?  There's something I've  been wondering about the whole  time:  This house, why has it  been empty all these years?  I  mean, I doubt if it was the  price. Lindner suddenly turns evasive and cool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess it's too lonely for  most folks. (glances at his watch)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's time for me to get going.  It's been a pleasure meeting  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait, won't you join me for a  cup of coffee? He turns down the offer, a touch too vehemently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, thank you.  I need to get  back home.  My wife is waiting. He leaves.  Ellen contemplatively watches him go. Martin enters the kitchen and puts his arms around her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who was that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone from the village. She turns around to face him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin, there's something I...  uh... need to tell you about.

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Martin is seated in the old armchair.  Ellen across from  him.  He is grinning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, now let me see if I've  got this straight.  First you  get warnings from a road sign  and then from the weather  forecast.  Which one of us two  was the author again? Ellen feels disappointed and misunderstood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin, it's not funny!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, it's not always easy  for me, either.  But at least I  try not to give in to each and  every neurosis. Now he's got her angry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, apparently it was a big  mistake to try talking to you.  Don't you remember what we  promised to each other?   Honesty - trust!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, this isn't about  honesty.  You just need a good  night's sleep.  The way you  toss and turn all night, even I  hardly get any sleep. Ellen realizes there is no use in discussing this any  further.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, excuse me for having  bothered you with my problems. She leaves the living room and walks out on Martin.

dialogues.speaker: HALLWAY
dialogues.text: Ellen is using a spatula to scratch the old-fashioned,  yellowed wallpaper off of the walls.  She is still upset, and really taking it out on the wallpaper. Martin comes walking up the steps.  He is carrying a plat full of small, deformed cakes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For you. He holds out the plate to her.  Ellen throws a skeptical  look at the mishap pastry.  She won't be bribed this  easily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, what did I do to deserve  this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, at least try one.  It  took me two hours to make  these. Ellen goes back to scratching off the wallpaper.  Martin  changes his tactic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What I really meant to say was:  I'm sorry.  I'm a real bonehead  sometimes.  But it's just that  I'm worried about you.  I'm  afraid you might get carried  away with something like that. Ellen interrupts her work and takes one of the cakes.  Sh tastes it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tastes awful. She grins.  Martin returns a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But baked with lots of love. Martin helps himself to a small cake, too.  He bites off piece, and makes a sour face.  Then, he takes Ellen's pie out of her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I'd better get rid of  this.  After all, I don't want  to kill you. He turns to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin... Martin stops at the bottom of the staircase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Maybe you're right and I  just need to get some sleep.   Don't worry.  I'll get settled  in sooner or later.

dialogues.speaker: IN FRONT OF THE HOUSE
dialogues.text: The farmhouse lies in the loneliness of a starless night. Silhouettes of gnarled trees reach for the sky like black claws.

dialogues.speaker: ENTRANCE AREA
dialogues.text: It's dark.  An eerie silence fills the house. Suddenly, there is a CHILD'S VOICE calling in the distanc

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mommy...

dialogues.speaker: BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Martin and Ellen are asleep in their bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mommy! Ellen wakes up out of her light slumber.  She opens her  eyes and looks around, searching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tommi...? The voice clearly echoes through the house.  (It sounds  like Thomas' call before the accident.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mommy... Ellen silently sits up.  She is wide awake.  She tries to wake up Martin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin... did you hear that? No chance - Martin only mumbles a few unintelligible word and continues to sleep. Ellen gets out of bed.

dialogues.speaker: ENTRANCE AREA
dialogues.text: Almost mechanically, the child's calling repeats itself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mommy... Ellen carefully heads down the stairs, toward the entranc door.  The voice seems to be coming from outside. Ellen opens the door, frightened.

dialogues.speaker: IN FRONT OF THE HOUSE
dialogues.text: The pale moonlight dips the landscape into a ghostly  atmosphere. Ellen's eyes search through the darkness. There!  There is something in the distance.  A child!  Th child is standing in the tall grass, looking toward Ellen

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tommi? She cannot believe her eyes. It really is her little Thomas!  He smiles.  There is  something about the way he moves that makes it look as if he's floating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (louder)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tommi! The little boy laughs.  He turns around and runs away in  the grass; as if in play. Ellen snaps out of her stiffness and chases after him. The small figure slowly disappears in the increasingly ta grass.

dialogues.speaker: FOREST IN THE MOORS
dialogues.text: Ellen is running farther and farther away from the house. She stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tommi, wait! But the little boy keeps running further. Ellen follows him, but her path grows increasingly  toilsome.  Her feet sink deeper and deeper into the moor. Now, the child is out of sight. Ellen is devastated.  She trips and falls to the ground. The swamp encloses her.  Ellen fights against the marsh  that she is sinking into deeper and deeper. Suddenly, the little boy steps back out of the darkness. He stays a few feet away from Ellen.  He smiles as he  watches Ellen sink into the deadly swamp. With a sudden jerk, an unknown force pulls her down into  the moor.  She is swallowed by the earth.

dialogues.speaker: BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Ellen abruptly wakes up from her NIGHTMARE! She looks around herself.  She is in her comfortable  bedroom flooded with the warm rays of the morning sun.   Martin's side of the bed is already empty. Then, she hesitates.  Something feels wrong.  Ellen throw back her sheets.  Horror - her bed is full of mud. Ellen wants to scream.  She barely manages to suppress it

dialogues.speaker: STUDY / HALLWAY
dialogues.text: Martin is sitting at his computer, busily typing.  He see to be making progress on his book. In the background, Ellen hurries past the study.  She is  carrying the dirty sheets under her arm.  Without looking up from the monitor, Martin calls through the open door:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, did you sleep good?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling to Martin)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah... I have to go to town. Ellen enters the kitchen.  She hastily stuffs the bed- sheets into the washing machine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there anything you need? She turns the washing machine on and heads for the door.

dialogues.speaker: ENTRANCE AREA
dialogues.text: Ellen is about to leave the house.  The door is already  open.  In the entrance area, she finds the dog (that  Lindner had previously discovered in their garden) sittin in front of the cellar door. Ellen pets him in passing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the dog)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, you're still here.  I  suppose you like it here with  us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling from the study)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, thanks.  I have everything  I need.  Drive safely, you  hear? Ellen is already out the door.  She pulls it shut behind  her.

dialogues.speaker: CONSULTING ROOM OF PROF. ROTH
dialogues.text: A pleasantly decorated consulting room.  Standing by a  window is PROF. ULRICH ROTH (Professor of Psychiatry), a  distinguished man around 50 years of age.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see, there are various  approaches to an explanation  for what you are currently  going through. Ellen is hunched in a chair opposite of him. Prof. Roth turns around to face her and takes a seat behi his desk.  The leather chair creaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the latest theories  claim that at certain  frequencies, air conditioners  create an oscillation that can,  in fact, cause hallucinations.   They may also be due to the  interior pressure of your eyes  and so on and so forth.   Personally I believe that all  of this is nonsense.  The loss  of a child is a traumatic  experience. Subconsciously, you  may still be blaming yourself  for it, and maybe now believe  that your son should punish  you... Ellen impatiently cuts him short.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, it's one thing to have  a guilt complex. But I know the  difference between when I'm  overstrung and when I'm seeing  things that are simply not  there!  Besides, it only began  after we moved!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hesitantly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is, of course, another  possible explanation which I  dearly hope is not the case. Lost in thought, Prof. Roth taps his pen on his desktop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tumor - which could cause  pressure on certain parts of  the brain and, thus, influence  your perception. Ellen stares at him, shocked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just to be on the safe side, I  would like to have a few tests  done.

dialogues.speaker: COMPUTER TOMOGRAPH
dialogues.text: Ellen is lying on a stretcher, slowly being moved into th opening of the computer tomograph.  She is wearing a pale green hospital garment. The penetrating sound of the machines - technical coldnes

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR'S OFFICE
dialogues.text: Blood is filled into a cannula. Ellen is sitting on a stretcher.  The NURSE pulls the  needle out of her arm. DR. SCHLETH, a man who makes a somewhat lethargic  impression, enters the room and fastens the tomograph sho in front of an illuminated surface on the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Congratulations.  You are  definitely the healthiest  person I've had in CT for  years. Ellen heaves a sigh of relief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Roth gave me these for you.   Three times a day, after meals. He hands her a box of tablets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fluctin.  A pretty strong  antidepressive... If you asked  me, I'd try to do without them  first. He takes a look into her health records.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You come from Goldmoor? Ellen answers absent-mindedly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We just moved there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (by-the-way)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One time, when I was in  college, we examined a swamp  corpse in pathology.  They had  excavated it there. Now he has Ellen's attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three or four thousand years  old.  But I didn't deal with  the subject any more than  necessary.  You know, I never  liked pathology.  Somehow, I  always felt it reduced humans  to something they are not. Suddenly, Dr. Schleth's beeper goes off.  He takes a quic glance at it and turns to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Schleth. The doctor stops at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you believe happens to  a human after he dies? The otherwise reserved Dr. Schleth suddenly seems very  human.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean, do I believe in  something like a soul? He smiles mischievously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't seen one on any of my  x-ray pictures, yet.  But then  again, what would x-rays know? He turns around and walks out.  Lost in thought, Ellen  watches him leave.

dialogues.speaker: IN FRONT OF THE HOUSE
dialogues.text: Ellen steers the car into the driveway and climbs out.  T dog runs to greet her, wagging its tail.  Ellen kneels do in front of the dog and pets it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, girl!  Here, I brought you  something. She takes a collar with a little bell on it out of her  purse and puts it around the dog's neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now all we need is a name for  you.  How about Clara - okay,  then: Clara. She walks to the house door.  The dog follows her inside if it were the most natural thing to do.  The bell jingle

dialogues.speaker: ENTRANCE AREA
dialogues.text: Ellen enters the hallway.  At the same time, Martin comes upstairs from the cellar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, love.  Trouble with the  fuses again? Martin locks the door behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a real mess.  I think it'd  be better for you not to go  down there for a while.  It's  just too dangerous. He drops the key for the cellar into his pocket.  Ellen  watches this with irritation.  Martin's entire behavior  seems odd. Behind Ellen, the dog trots into the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't tell me you've made  friends with that wandering  flea circus?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?  She can guard the  house.  By the way, I gave her  a name: Clara. She pets the dog, not noticing the frown on Martin's face

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where have you been all day?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I went to see Prof. Roth!  You  know, I had another one of  those dreams last night.  I saw  Tommi! Suddenly, the look on Martin's face softens again.  He  takes Ellen into his arms to comfort her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ellen... our Tommi is dead.   And there's nothing we can do  about it. Ellen rests her head against his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, Martin, since we  moved to this house...  sometimes I just get the  feeling that the past is  catching up to us again... Martin interrupts her with unexpected ill temper and free himself from the hug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh!  Now we're getting to the  point!  So all of a sudden,  it's the house.  Yesterday, it  was a road sign.  And the first  thing you do is go and run to  "Dr. Freud"!  He heads for the study, leaving Ellen behind.  Ellen call after him:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But that's not the point!   What if all these things are  somehow connected?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, baloney.  You should just  hear yourself talk! He treads up the staircase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be in the study, just in  case you decide to get  reasonable, after all. Ellen watches him with consternation.  She goes into the  kitchen, worried.

dialogues.speaker: KITCHEN
dialogues.text: Lost in thought, Ellen takes out a cup and pours herself cup of coffee from a thermos.  She takes the pills that she got from Dr. Schleth out of  her purse and studies them. She looks out through the window, at the dreamlike  landscape of the moors.  There is a warm evening breeze. Suddenly, Ellen's eyes focus on the reflection of her fac in the window.  She faintly discerns something strange on her forehead: "4"! Startled, she touches her forehead.  There is nothing on  it. When she takes a second look at her reflection, everythin is normal again. The dog trots up to Ellen, whining balefully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the dog)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Either Martin is right or I am  really starting to lose my  mind... For a moment, she considers taking one of the tablets.  B then, she determinedly throws the whole package in the  trash can.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE VILLAGE
dialogues.text: Ellen parks her car in the center of the nearby village. The small township is smothering in a humid summer's heat Ellen heads for a bookstore with Clara trotting in behind

dialogues.speaker: AT THE BOOKSTORE
dialogues.text: Ellen enters the shop.  It is unusually dark and quiet in here.  She runs her fingers across the shelves, searching She passes by a stand with pocket books, also including  several copies of "Cherry-red Tears" next to Stephen King "Shining".  She stops for a moment.  Smiles. Then, she finds the department for books on psychology.   She pulls out a book titled "The Inner Child - The Ghosts of the Past".  Leafs through it.  She stops at a certain  page:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly reads to herself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "...certain places arouse  recollections and links within  us..." Suddenly, Ellen hears a voice behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First buy it, then read it! Ellen looks up.  The sales lady is standing in front of  her:  a skinny woman with small eyes suspiciously beaming at Ellen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, of course... I'll take it. She places the book on the counter.  All of a sudden, the sales lady has turned into the world's most friendly  person.  Ellen follows her to the cash register and gives her the book. The sales lady skeptically eyes the psychology book while she notes the price. Ellen puts the money on the counter and turns to leave th store, when the sales lady speaks up again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're the wife of that author,  aren't you? Ellen turns back to face her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin Straub, yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Used to write some nice books,  your husband.  But that last  one was awful.  A terrible  book.  Didn't sell, either. Ellen really can't think of an answer to that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I read it - violent trash.  My  husband said so, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I've got to get going...  'bye. Ellen walks out of the shop.  The sales lady keeps talkin Her eyes are cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (loud)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's bad and it's violent.  I  don't like that kind of stuff.   Tell that to your husband.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE BOOKSTORE
dialogues.text: Clara is still waiting in front of the bookstore when Ell comes back outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Clara.  Let's get out  of here. Just as she sets out for her car, she discovers Karl  Lindner and his wife.  He seems to want to pass by her  without saying hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Lindner! Lindner realizes he has no way out of this situation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Mrs. Straub.  May I  introduce you to my wife?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just call me Elisabeth. She seems like a truly honest person and very awake,  despite her advanced age.  Ellen shakes hands with her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ellen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're doing fine, aren't you?   I mean... the two of you alone  in that house, so far out in  the moor. Lindner nudges his wife with his elbow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the moor? What do you mean  by that? Mrs. Lindner wants to answer something, but her husband  heads her off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop scaring people.  Let's go.   We need to be on our way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse us.  But do stop by for  a visit sometime!  You are  welcome anytime. Lindner manages a smile and leads his wife away by the ar

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have a nice day. As soon as they are out of hearing distance, Mrs. Lindner tells her husband with obvious anger:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quiet, reproachfully)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't tell her!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We should leave the past alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it will never leave us  alone as long as you ignore it. Back to Ellen:  She watches the two of them go for a  moment.  Then, she gets into her car and drives off.

dialogues.speaker: STUDY
dialogues.text: Martin is in the study, working at his computer.  He is i a writing frenzy, typing in the words like a madman.  Ell comes through the door.  She is carrying the book about  Goldmoor in her hand.  At first, Martin does not react to her.  He keeps on typing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It seems to be going well for  you. Martin continues to type as he speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where have you been?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the village.  Look what I  found. She opens the book to a certain page and holds it under h nose. Martin is annoyed for having to interrupt his work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Psychology, huh?  So, what side  of the rainbow are we on today? Ellen points out a certain passage in the book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reads out loud)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Events commonly interpreted as  haunting apparitions often  result from psychic  disharmonies or undigested  traumatic ordeals..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impatient)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ellen, what are you trying to  prove, anyway?  That we've  created ourselves a ghost?   Come on! Ellen persistently tries to get through to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just a feeling.  Don't you  sense it, too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? What am I supposed to  sense?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The house - Tommi - something  just doesn't jive here... Suddenly, Martin's voice gets disproportionately loud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now you go starting that again.   We decided together, to build  up something new here.  I, for  my part, am working on it very  hard.  But oddly, you seem to  have changed your mind. Ellen wants to reply something but just then, the doorbel RINGS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't the slightest idea. When she sees that Martin does not intend to answer the  door, Ellen goes downstairs herself.

dialogues.speaker: ENTRANCE AREA
dialogues.text: Ellen opens the door.  Standing in the doorway are Paul a Claudia, both in the best of moods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Surprise! Ellen hugs them, her mind still halfway on Martin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, this really is a  surprise!  Come on in! Martin comes downstairs.  He seems anything but pleased b the company. Paul gives him a jovial pat on the shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, my man!  How's the  masterpiece coming along?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not so bad, if I could get some  peace and quiet around here. Paul understands the side-swipe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, hey, hey!  Say no more  until you've seen what we  brought: He puts a wide grin on his face.  Ellen and Martin exchan quick looks.  Paul pulls something out from behind his  back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scrabble!

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Martin looks annoyed.  The four friends are comfortably  seated around the living room table.  Each of them has a  glass of wine. While they play Scrabble, Paul tells a dirty story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, you should've seen him!   Elke Schneider enters the room  and storms up to him.  She is  tremendous.  Her breasts are so  big that just recently, there  was a discussion about whether  they should be given country  names of their own. Laughter all around the table. Martin is the only one who is not delighted.  But Ellen is clearly relieved by this  moment of normality in the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul, you and your stories...  I've really missed you! Claudia looks around the living room.  Apparently, she  likes what she's seeing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm impressed!  You two have  really gotten quite a bit done,  already. The sack with the Scrabble-letters is passed on to Ellen. She reaches inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think?  We worked  our fingers to the bone and  now, we're both about to have a  nervous breakdown. Ellen places the letters on the table in front of her and begins to shuffle them back and forth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I really wouldn't have thought  you two could stand it out here  for this long.  To tell the  truth, we even have some bets  going with a couple of  people... But Ellen isn't paying attention to Claudia's words any  more.  Terrified, she stares at her Scrabble-stones, whic she has already put together.  The letters form the words

dialogues.speaker: T-H-R-E-E--D-A-Y-S
dialogues.text: Everyone is waiting for her to make her turn.  Paul start nagging.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well?  Are you going to play? Ellen feverishly gathers up her letter stones and throws  them back into the sack.  She shakes it with special  thoroughness and draws anew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I pass. Paul is pleased.  He puts down his word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Triple word score, that makes  72 points.  Now what do you say  to that, honey-bunny?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My hero. They kiss. Ellen lines up her newly drawn stones in front of herself again.  Martin watches her. Ellen cannot believe her eyes.  Again, her letter  combination spells out:

dialogues.speaker: T-H-R-E-E--D-A-Y-S
dialogues.text: This time, the others notice the look on Ellen's face, to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ellen, what's wrong? It takes Ellen a moment to answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just got exactly the same  letters for the second time. She gives Martin a significant look and shows him her  letter-board.  This time, she has proof!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sarcastically)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, "three days".  A new  message! He turns to Paul and Claudia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because - you know - Ellen is  receiving messages from road  signs, radio broadcasters and  now from Scrabble game stones. He turns Ellen's letter-board around for the others to se Martin's reaction hits Ellen like a fist.  She feels  humiliated.  She is at a loss for words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the best part is:  She  thinks the messages are meant  to announce her death. (makes a "spooky" noise)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooooo... Claudia looks back and forth between Martin and Ellen.  S realizes how serious the situation is.  As opposed to Pau who pulls out a news ARTICLE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Talk about spooky.  Martin, do  you remember that splintered  door to the study?  I guess  there was more to it than just  a lost key. The headline of the article reads: "Murder in Goldmoor -  Many questions remain unanswered".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me see that! Ellen takes the article.  The picture underneath shows Ka Lindner in police uniform, 23 years younger. Before she even has a chance to read the article, Martin  grabs the newspaper out of her hands. He crumples up the paper and angrily turns to Paul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just perfect, Paul!  Well done!   Can't you tell that my wife is  upset enough already?  And then  you come up with this kind of a  story?! Ellen has regained her composure.  She is still outraged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think you're doing,  anyway?  Now give me back that  article! Martin shows no sign of reaction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ellen, I just don't want you to  get upset for no reason. He tries to conciliate by putting his arm on her shoulder But Ellen shakes him off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sarcastic)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How thoughtful of you! An unpleasant moment of silence.  Ellen looks at Claudia  and Paul - she doesn't want to make a fool of herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me for a moment. She storms out of the room. Paul and Claudia both look a bit sheepish. Martin holds the article to a candle and burns it in an  ashtray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She shouldn't be worrying about  this stuff.  Lately, she's been  acting strange enough already.

dialogues.speaker: IN FRONT OF THE HOUSE
dialogues.text: Ellen is standing in front of the house.  Lost in thought she takes a drag from her cigarette. Claudia comes out of the house and joins her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this going on between  you two?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I don't know.  I was hoping  things would get better once we  moved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But nothing got any better? Ellen's eyes wander over the vast landscape of moors whic the darkness of the night has transformed into a surreal  shadow painting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lately, Martin hasn't been his  normal self.  The work, the  relocation...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have to give him some time,  Ellen.  He's under enormous  pressure right now.  He hasn't  written a single decent  sentence since the accident. Ellen takes a last long drag from her cigarette, throws i on the ground and puts it out with her foot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I know.  I try my best.   It's just that... sometimes I  wonder if we made a mistake by  moving here.

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Martin and Paul are still seated opposite each other.  A  strange atmosphere.  Paul is trying hard to keep up a  conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, work is going well, you  say? Martin makes a very calm impression.  In the background,  the dog is barking at the cellar door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calmly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  Splendid.  I finally  found a story that's both:   thrilling and true to life. Now, Clara starts to bark at the cellar door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm glad to hear that.  You  know... Martin has a sudden outburst and yells:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the dog)

dialogues.speaker: NOW SHUT UP, YOU STUPID BITCH
dialogues.text: Paul is all confused now.  He throws a helpless look towa the entrance door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, I think I have to get  up early in the morning.  We  ought to get going.

dialogues.speaker: ENTRANCE AREA
dialogues.text: Clara is still barking at the cellar door.  Then, she  starts to claw at the crack below the door, as if she had discovered something behind it.

dialogues.speaker: IN FRONT OF THE HOUSE
dialogues.text: The next morning: The house is enclosed in a light curtain of early morning fog.  Everything seems oddly quiet.  Not a single bird is chirping. The calm before the storm.

dialogues.speaker: BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Ellen wakes up out of her light sleep.  She looks around. Martin's side of the bed is empty and unused.  Martin did not spend the night by her side.

dialogues.speaker: KITCHEN
dialogues.text: Ellen enters the kitchen in her bathrobe.  She puts on a  pot of coffee.  Martin comes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, darling. Ellen turns around to face him.  She is terror-stricken. His hands are covered with blood.  He seems to be oblivio to it.  In the best of moods, he walks to the kitchen sin while he continues to speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At last, I'm back on top!   Seventy pages in one night!   I'd say that just about breaks  the record... He starts washing his hands with meticulous care.  The re stained water runs into the drain. Ellen closes her eyes and fights the panic welling up  inside of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ellen?  Is everything alright? She opens her eyes again.  She takes a second look and se that what she thought to be blood is only wall paint.  Sh discovers a bucket with a paintbrush beside the kitchen  door. She tries to conceal her thoughts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, sure.  I'm just a little...  dizzy. She hastily grabs the dog's food dish and fills it. -  Simply to be doing something; anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ought to give Clara something  to eat. Ellen goes outside.

dialogues.speaker: IN FRONT OF THE HOUSE
dialogues.text: Ellen carries the dish outside and starts searching for  Clara.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clara! Nothing stirs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come here, Clara!  I've got  something yummy for you. Then, she catches sight of something dark lying a bit awa in the grass. Ellen puts down the dog food and runs toward the spot. There, lying in the tall grass she finds the dog.  It's  dead!  It looks as if a wild animal had attacked Clara.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no! (loud)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin! She kneels down beside the animal's dead body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (screams)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin! Martin comes out of the house and stops at the door.  He calm - too calm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at this!  The dog!  She's  dead! Martin shows no reaction.  He doesn't even seem to find i worth the trouble to go over to Ellen who is still kneeli in the grass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was old.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Old?!  Come look at this!  She  has wounds.  Wounds on her  head.  Like thrashes.  Or  bites.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe an animal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (furious)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An animal?  What kind of  animal?   A goddamned T-Rex, or what? Martin is still apathetically standing in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She spent a couple of pleasant  days with us, and now she's  dead.  That's the way it is.   I'm sorry.  I have work to do. He goes back inside. Ellen watches him. This very instant, she realizes that this is not the man  she once married.  She knows that the time has come to ta up action.

dialogues.speaker: MOOR
dialogues.text: A short distance away from the house, Ellen has buried th dog.  She sticks a small, self-built wooden crucifix into the soft earth. She stands there for a moment.  She looks over at the  house.  Silence.  Loneliness. Then, she hangs Clara's collar over the cross.  The littl bell jingles.

dialogues.speaker: COUNTRY ROAD
dialogues.text: Ellen speeds down the country road in her car.  She passe the town sign of Goldmoor.  She has a tense look on her  face.

dialogues.speaker: IN FRONT OF LINDNER'S HOUSE
dialogues.text: Ellen rings the doorbell. She is standing in front of Lindner's house.  While she  waits, she looks up and down the street.  There is no one in sight. The entire village seems deserted. Elisabeth Lindner opens the door.  She doesn't seem very  surprised to see Ellen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Ellen!  I've been wondering  when you'd come.  Why don't you  step in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. Ellen enters the house.

dialogues.speaker: HALLWAY IN LINDNER'S HOUSE
dialogues.text: The hallway is dark.  The wood-paneled walls are decorate with pictures and certificates from Karl Lindner's years a police officer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My husband is in his study in  the back. Mrs. Lindner leads Ellen through the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I really hate to bother him,  but...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no, no.  You're not  bothering him. (she winks an eye)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has lots of time since he's  been retired.

dialogues.speaker: LINDNER'S STUDY
dialogues.text: Ellen enters the spacious study.  Lindner is seated in  front of an easel, dexterously painting lines onto a  canvas.  He is working on a still life of flowers. Without turning around to Ellen, he says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come in. Ellen takes a look around the room.  It is also furnished in dark colors, and there are dozens of oil paintings  standing around the room.  Every single one a still life flowers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You only draw flowers?  A  little unusual for a former  policeman. Lindner obstinately continues to work on his painting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, after doing that job  for so many years, you learn to  appreciate the simple things in  life.  Flowers incorporate a  beauty that I always missed in  life.  But certainly, you're  not here to chat about my  hobbies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 1976.  What happened back then? With a heavy heart, he puts down his paintbrush and turns to face Ellen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do yourself a favor:  Don't  ask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I appreciate your concern, but  we live in that house.  I need  to know what happened in there. Lindner turns back to his painting and continues to draw. He seems introverted, as if he were talking to himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We found the wife about a week  after she had died, hunched in  her TV-chair.  Her husband was  sitting in front of her; the  whole time, he sat in front of  her dead body.  A whole damn  week.  Her death certificate  says that she drowned, and her  husband was convicted, but God  alone knows what really  happened back then. Ellen is shocked.  Still, she persists.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What made him do it? Lindner doesn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That man, is he still alive?   Where is he?  Can I talk to  him? Lindner turns around to her again.  This time, he looks  determined.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you just leave the  past alone and now go - please. Ellen sees that it's no use.  She turns to leave.  But sh stops at the door and turns back once more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If there's one thing I've  learned lately, it's that you  can not run away from the past.   Believe me. She leaves the old policeman behind.  Once alone, he lowe his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: IN FRONT OF LINDNER'S HOUSE
dialogues.text: Ellen leaves the house, reflective.  Just as she heads  through the gate, Mrs. Lindner catches up with her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ellen!  Wait! She hands Ellen a small note.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank Kosinski.  Here's the  address.  Go see him.  Ask him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.  Elisabeth, I didn't  mean to... Mrs. Lindner puts it off with a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's alright.  Don't  misunderstand my husband.  It's  only that he's already had  enough problems with this case. And who would believe him if he  told the truth?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what is the truth?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know all about what  happened back then.  But it  always stood between me and my  husband. Ellen nods and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: PSYCHIATRY
dialogues.text: Ellen parks her car in front of the large, old building. She opens the heavy double doors of the entrance.

dialogues.speaker: PSYCHIATRY
dialogues.text: A long, wood-paneled hallway with small resting areas.   Some of the elderly people are sitting around, others are playing cards or staring at a television - a strange  atmosphere. Ellen approaches a SOCIAL WORKER, who is pushing an OLD  LADY through the hallway in a wheelchair. The old lady giggles, as if she were mentally disoriented

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, I'm looking for  Frank Kosinski. The young man is of the silly, bored type.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kosinski... (thinks for a moment)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh - you mean K.K.!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry? The social worker grins.  He seems to think he's very  funny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Killer-Kosinski, that's what  they call him around here.  He  did away with his wife. Now, the old lady joins in on the conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so glad you finally came.   We've all been waiting for you. She gently touches Ellen's hand. - The old lady seems to taking Ellen for someone else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly, to the old lady)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must be mistaking me. (to the young man)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where can I find the man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's in the closed psychiatry.  This here's the open section.  Go down the hall, third door to  the left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. The old lady keeps on persisting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you doing better yet? Ellen is too preoccupied to worry about the old lady.  Sh leaves them with a quick nod and hurries on. The social worker starts pushing the wheelchair forward  again.  Walking away, Ellen still hears the old lady's  voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to social worker)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poor girl.  She only has two  more days to live, you know. Ellen stops.  She turns on her heels and runs back. She excitedly stops the wheelchair and leans over to the  old lady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was that?  What did you  say? The old lady doesn't seem to recognize her any more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want from me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you just said, about the  two days...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't say anything! Ellen looks at the social worker, hoping that he might  help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't hear anything.  Sorry. Ellen doubtfully looks back and forth between the two of  them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry...  I guess I was  mistaken. She quickly turns her back to this embarrassing situation and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: HALLWAY OUTSIDE OF KOSINSKI'S CELL
dialogues.text: The MALE NURSE turns the key.  Before opening the heavy  door, he gives Ellen a questioning look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has his clear moments every  now and then.  But I wouldn't  get my hopes up high. They both enter the cell.

dialogues.speaker: KOSINSKI'S CELL
dialogues.text: Frank Kosinski (approx. 70 years old now) is sitting at a desk.  He is busy putting newspaper articles into clear  plastic folders and carefully sorting them away. Ellen enters the room.  The nurse closes the door from  inside and stays standing next to it.   The room looks more like an office archive than the cell a closed psychiatric clinic.  There are several shelves  filled with neatly lined up files.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Kosinski? The old man takes no notice of her.  Ellen steps up to hi obviously feeling very uncomfortable about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Kosinski, my name is Ellen  Straub.  I live in your house  out in Goldmoor... I mean, the  house where you used to live.   There are a few questions I  would like to ask you. Kosinski does not react.  He seems so lost in his own wor that he hasn't even registered her presence.  He stubborn continues sorting his papers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Kosinski!  Can you hear me? She waves her hand in front of his face.  No reaction. Ellen realizes that she'll have to come up with something else. She walks to one of the shelves and pulls out a file titl "1976".  Leafs through it.  She finds the article that Pa had brought the other night. She lays it on the desk, right in front of Kosinski's nos

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 1976 - What happened back then?   You... Now, she has his attention.  As if she had pushed the  button of a tape recorder, Kosinski immediately begins to recite the article.  He seems to know it by heart.

dialogues.speaker: KOSINSKI
dialogues.text: "October 4, 1976.  To this day,  the cold-blooded murder at the  remote homestead continues to  bring up questions.   Investigations have shown no  satisfactory results.  As was  announced by a police spokesman
Ellen gives the nurse a questioning look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never mind, it's his usual  number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
