dialogues.text: Yes.  That's right.  What  happened back then? Although Kosinski has the news article right in front of  him, he seems to be staring at the air.  Ellen tests him taking away the news report.  Kosinski continues to recit

dialogues.speaker: KOSINSKI
dialogues.text: "... another unsolved mystery  is the question, why doors and  windows had been nailed shut.   The murder suspect and only  witness is still in a state of  mental derangement. ..." Again, Ellen tries to interrupt him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, fine.  I read that.  It's  written in the article.  What I  want to know is:  What really  happened back then? Kosinski mechanically continues to speak.  Absolutely  inanimate.

dialogues.speaker: KOSINSKI
dialogues.text: "... Friends and family  describe him as a friendly,  reliable husband.  He had been  forced into closing his small  trades business after  bankruptcy.  It is uncertain  whether this might have been  cause for marital dispute..." Ellen realizes that she cannot get through to him with  words.  She finds a page on the desk that was torn out of chronicle about Goldmoor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: August 17, 1869.

dialogues.speaker: KOSINSKI
dialogues.text: "August 17, 1869.  A messenger  found Mr. and Mrs. Eugen and  Wilhelmine Meister dead in  their house."   With both astonishment and dismay, Ellen listens to the o man's monotonous lecture.

dialogues.speaker: KOSINSKI
dialogues.text: "...The police constable in  charge found no traces.  The  motive of the crime remains a  mystery..." Ellen turns to the nurse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could I please speak with him  alone for a moment?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be fine.  Thank you. The nurse leaves the cell with a frown. Ellen takes Kosinski's chair and turns him around.  She  looks straight into his blank eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am starting to get the  impression that all of this is  some kind of bad joke:  I'm  seeing things that are not  there, my own husband is  becoming a total stranger and  your old friend Lindner won't  tell me what he knows.  I have  no idea what you're trying to  prove with this performance of  yours, but I am not leaving  this room before I hear the  truth. No reaction.  Kosinski continues to stare at nothing in  particular.  Ellen gives up.  Shaking her head, she turns to the door.

dialogues.speaker: KOSINSKI
dialogues.text: It's a grave. Ellen freezes and looks back at Kosinski.  She walks back over to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Suddenly, Kosinski seems to have snapped out of his  "autism".  He is holding an old book in his hands.  The  book contains clippings, notes and among others, a page  that seems to have been torn out of another book. It is an etching from the Middle Ages illustrating a man  being pushed into the swamp by several villagers. Ellen reads the text underneath the illustration:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "...Execution in the moor..." All of a sudden, Kosinski grabs Ellen and pulls her close His eyes have a feverish glow.

dialogues.speaker: KOSINSKI
dialogues.text: The moor... it's one big grave.

dialogues.speaker: ENTRANCE AREA / HALLWAY
dialogues.text: Ellen enters the hallway.  She runs into Martin who is on his way up from the cellar. When he sees Ellen, he shuts the cellar door and puts the key into his pocket again.  It seems as if he felt caught doing something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sarcastic)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me guess:  Another short  circuit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, darling. Martin ignores her comment and starts to head up the stai to his study.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is going on down there,  anyway?  Why am I not supposed  to go in the cellar? Martin stops at the base of the stairway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you:  It's too  dangerous.  Besides, I have to  work now. He continues up the staircase.  Ellen follows him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin, we need to talk.  I've  done some research.  This  lovely house of ours has a  history of murder cases. Martin does not stop walking, but his eyes show alarm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyone who ever lived in this  house either quickly moved back  out, or fell victim to strange  accidents, or ended up killing  each other.

dialogues.speaker: STUDY
dialogues.text: Martin sits down at his desk and immediately starts typin Ellen won't give up so easy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you don't believe me,  but at least hear me out.   Don't tell me you haven't  noticed that we've been going  through some strange changes  since we moved here! We hardly talk to each other  any more, you're writing like a  madman and I'm having these  visions. Martin does not interrupt his work. Ellen slams the articles from Kosinski on his keyboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here, look at this!  Did you  know that our house is built  right on a spot where during  the Middle Ages people were  executed?  They simply threw  the convicts into the moors,  alive. Martin shakes his head.  He smiles and shoves the article aside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: During the Middle Ages people  were executed at every corner.   What's your point?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This house, the whole damned  area around here is one mass  grave...  Now you might call me  crazy, but there is something  negative about the place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, so the house has a  history and there might still  be a couple of corpses in the  moors. (mocking)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "There is something negative  about the place..."  What the  hell are you trying to say?   Come on!  Spit it out! Ellen twists around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's like... a sickness!  And  it's gotten into our heads. Now Martin gets aggressive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you finally cut it out?   Just in case you haven't  noticed, I am trying to write a  book here.  And maybe - even  with your birdbrains - you can  figure it's a pretty tough job. So why can't you just leave me  alone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn it, look at you!  Don't  you see what's happening with  you?  We need to get out of  here, don't you understand?   Out of this house! Martin threatens her with his forefinger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now let me work! Martin continues to write.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hollers)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To hell with your damned work! In a rash action, she suddenly pushes his computer monito off of the desk. Martin jumps up from his chair.  He grabs Ellen by the  throat and pushes her against the wall.  Throbbing veins his forehead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you dare... Ellen can hardly breathe.  She is about to choke.  Just i time, Martin lets go. Ellen slides to the floor and gasps for air. Martin doesn't seem to care.  He sets the monitor back on the table and gets back to work. Ellen is deeply shocked.  She drags herself out of the  room. Martin doesn't even deign to look up at her again.

dialogues.speaker: HALLWAY
dialogues.text: The door to the study falls shut behind Ellen. Slowly, she sinks to her knees and starts to cry.   Hopelessness and despair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sobbing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin... oh my God... what's  happening to us... The house is dead-silent.  Only the sound of Martin typin on his computer keyboard in his study. Suddenly, Ellen hears a noise - very quiet.  It is the  RINGING of a bell. Ellen looks up. There it is again, very clearly:  It's the bell on the  collar of the dead dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly, to herself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clara...? She stands up and heads for the staircase.  Cautiously. A shadow rushes through the entrance hall - the shadow of dog. Ellen sneaks down the steps.  Her eyes scan the darkness.

dialogues.speaker: ENTRANCE AREA
dialogues.text: Again, the BELL RINGING.  The shadow.  The animal seems t have run into the cellar. Now, Ellen notices that the door Martin had locked so  carefully earlier, is open. A dirty-yellow gleam shines into the hallway from below. Ellen looks up - Martin seems to be working:  His steady  typing resounds throughout the house. It takes Ellen all the courage she has, but finally she  makes herself go into the cellar...

dialogues.speaker: STUDY
dialogues.text: Martin stops typing in mid-sentence.  He looks up.  There is a threatening gleam in his eyes...

dialogues.speaker: CELLAR
dialogues.text: Ellen carefully walks down the stairs to the cellar.  It' cold.  The single light bulb at the ceiling hardly sheds  any light.  An eerie and unsettling atmosphere. No sign of the dog. Ellen finds the fuse box.  No difference - the wires are  still hanging out of the wall, tangled up and rotten. All of a sudden, there is a voice coming from behind Elle

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mommy... Ellen spins around. There's something in the darkness - a figure:  Tommi! Ellen freezes.  Her eyes are glued to the little boy, who figure melts together with the shadows.  Like a tape  recording, he repeats:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mommy... Ellen fights up against the image as if she knew that it only a lie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No... The boy steps out of the shadow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mommy... Ellen backs off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My son is dead... The little boy comes closer.  Now, he is standing right i front of Ellen.  He raises his hands as if he wanted to b hugged.  Again, his sad voice repeats:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mommy! Finally, Ellen's heart wins over reason.  She falls to he knees and takes the boy into her arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My God, Tommi. Tears run down her cheeks.  She holds the child close.  B what she doesn't see: The boy's mean smile behind her bac Suddenly, there is a strange transformation:  Running  through Ellen's fingers - little at first, but then more  and more:  mud! Thomas' body has turned into liquid in her arms.  Ellen i devastated. Right before her eyes, the child dissolves into swamp mud It drains away and disappears in the floor. Time seems to stand still. Suddenly, Ellen is grabbed by the hair and torn around. It's Martin!  He stares at her resentfully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't I tell you not to go in  the cellar?! Ellen does not understand what's happening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin, what-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's simply too dangerous here!   But no, you always have to have  it your way. She tries to squirm out of his grip - but it's no use. Martin drags her up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what I have to do now,   and believe me:  I don't enjoy  doing this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin, damnit, what are you up  to?  Let go of me!

dialogues.speaker: ENTRANCE AREA
dialogues.text: Martin mercilessly drags Ellen along behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course you'll give me the  blame again.  Like back then.   Just a tiny cut and he could  still be alive today - isn't  that right, Ellen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about- Ellen tries to find a way to free herself.  But she hardl stands a chance against Martin's strength.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enough of that!  I know what I  have to do now. Sliding by, Ellen bumps into a tool box.  She gets hold o a screwdriver.  Panic-stricken, she thrusts it in Martin's direction. A scream of pain.  He collapses.  Bleeds. Ellen tears herself loose and runs out of the house.

dialogues.speaker: IN FRONT OF THE HOUSE / CAR
dialogues.text: Ellen races to the car and jumps in behind the steering  wheel. Martin staggers out in pursuit of her.  He is holding his stomach. Inside the car: Ellen hastily crams out the car key.  It slips out of her hand. Martin is coming closer. Inside the car: Ellen gropes around in the darkness, trying to find the  key. Martin has almost reached the car. Inside the car: At last, Ellen has the key.  She pushes it into the  ignition, turns it around.  The engine roars up. Ellen careens off in the car.  She brushes Martin.  He  spins away with a loud thud. The car speeds off.

dialogues.speaker: CONSULTING ROOM OF PROF. ROTH
dialogues.text: Prof. Roth is in the middle of a conference with two  INTERNS. The door flies open.  Ellen storms into the room with tea in her eyes; she is totally frantic. Her appearance surprises him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Straub!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've killed my husband!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I've killed him.   Martin, my husband, I've killed  him!  That is, I'm not sure,  but... Prof. Roth immediately takes her arm and leads her to a  sofa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Straub!  Now calm down  first. Ellen is totally distraught.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hectic, loud)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It all went so fast.  He was  out of his mind and then all of  sudden there was this  screwdriver.  I only wanted to  defend myself.  You have to  call the police...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can do all of that later,  but first you need to calm  down. He stands up, fetches a glass of water and takes a tablet out of a package.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here, take this. Ellen takes the pill without a moment's hesitation and  swallows it with a drink of water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I... I don't know which part of  it all really happened... It's  all one big nightmare... Prof. Roth sees that she is not able to think clearly at  the moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are going to sleep for a  little while, now.  And then,  we'll talk about it more calmly  and sift through all of this. The tablet quickly begins to show an effect.  In Ellen's  eyes, Prof. Roth's face gets blurry. One of the interns speaks up.

dialogues.speaker: INTERN
dialogues.text: Should we inform the  authorities? Prof. Roth waves it off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before everyone gets all  nervous, why don't you call her  house.  Maybe that will clear  things up. Ellen only vaguely catches the last spoken sentences  through a curtain of haze.  Then, she loses conscience.

dialogues.speaker: HOSPITAL ROOM
dialogues.text: Ellen drowsily wakes up in a hospital room.  She takes a  careful look around herself.  The room is surprisingly ni and pleasantly furnished.

dialogues.speaker: HOSPITAL CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: There is a lot going on in the hospital corridor.   MALE and FEMALE NURSES busily take care of their duties. A hand picks up a syringe and an ampoule from a trolley.

dialogues.speaker: HOSPITAL ROOM
dialogues.text: The door is opened. Ellen barely manages to lift her head in order to see who the visitor is. A man pulls a wheelchair inside with his back turned to  her, and closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Professor Roth? The man turns around: It's Martin! He is wearing his best suit.  He shows no signs of a woun Ellen wants to call for help, but Martin is already up ne to her and holds her mouth shut with his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, darling.  Are you  feeling better? He thrusts the syringe into her leg. Ellen desperately searches for the emergency button for t nurses' room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispers)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shh... everything will be fine.   Tomorrow, it will all be over.   Just don't try to fight it. Ellen has found the button, but the medication is faster: She doesn't have enough strength to push the button any  more. Her tired eyes blink and fall shut for a moment...

dialogues.speaker: BEDROOM
dialogues.text: ... Ellen's eyes slowly open again.  She wakes up to a lo HAMMERING noise. Only now does she realize that she is lying on the planki of her own bed, with her hands and feet roped tight.   Martin has put a gag in her mouth.  He is standing by the window, nailing several large boards in front of it.   He is so preoccupied with his work that he hasn't yet  noticed that Ellen is awake.  He quietly curses under his voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You stupid little bitch...   think you can toy around with  people any old way you like.   But not me, no. Ellen carefully tries to loosen the ropes.  The sound  catches Martin's attention.  He turns around to her.  He still holding a nail in the corner of his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sweetly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh sweetheart, you're awake  already? He takes the nail out of the corner of his mouth and open his suit jacket.  Underneath, we see his blood-soaked  shirt.  But he doesn't seem to feel any pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That really wasn't very nice of  you yesterday.  I always  thought you loved me.  You  know, I bet any other husband  would be pretty upset with you  now. He sits down on the bed next to her and begins to loosen  her gag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I believe in our  relationship.  What are such  trifles compared to that. He takes the gag out of her mouth.  Ellen's voice is  shaking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin, for heaven's sake, tie  me loose! Martin seriously shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Believe me, I'd really like to.   But I have the feeling you're  not ready yet. Ellen lies there, totally helpless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ready?  For what?  This is  crazy!  Don't you see what's  going on here? He moves closer to her, caresses her cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The last day, Ellen.  Today is  the last day.  The circle is  closing. Ellen suddenly understands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You knew! Martin slowly leans over and kisses her.  Ellen tries to  turn her head away, but Martin holds it tight.  Barbaric there is nothing tender about this kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Ellen.  My sweet Ellen...  Of course I knew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We loved each other once.  Have  you forgotten that? Martin seems bitter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah?  Did we really?   Think about it, Ellen... Just then, the DOORBELL rings.  They both look toward the door. Quick as a flash, Martin presses his hand on Ellen's mout so she cannot scream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you expecting company?

dialogues.speaker: IN FRONT OF THE HOUSE
dialogues.text: Karl Lindner is standing at the door.  He presses the  doorbell button.  He is carrying one of his flower  paintings under his arm.

dialogues.speaker: BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Martin puts the gag back into Ellen's mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make yourself comfortable.   I'll be right back. He stands up and leaves the room. Ellen hears him lock the door from outside.  She  immediately begins to tear at her ropes.

dialogues.speaker: HALLWAY / ENTRANCE AREA
dialogues.text: The doorbell RINGS again.  While Martin runs downstairs, buttons up his suit jacket again in order to conceal the  blood stains. He is still holding the hammer in his hand. He walks to the door and opens it to Lindner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening.  Karl Lindner.   I'm a friend of your wife.  Is  she in?

dialogues.speaker: BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Ellen is still tied to the bed.  She faintly hears the tw men's VOICES from downstairs. She moves her head, trying to get rid of the gag - in vai Ellen screams, but only muffled sounds come out. She doubles her efforts and tears at her ropes with all h might.

dialogues.speaker: IN FRONT OF THE HOUSE / ENTRANCE AREA
dialogues.text: Martin is standing across from Lindner.  He gives him a  friendly smile.  He shows no apparent signs of the  condition he is in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ellen is home.  But she isn't  feeling well.  Can I give her a  message? Lindner takes the painting out from under his arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, then I guess that makes my  gift all the more appropriate.   Maybe I'll just give it to her  real quick and be on my way  again. Martin anxiously fingers the hammer in his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um, I don't think that's a good  idea.  She went to lie down.  I  think she's already asleep.   She's been pretty busy lately  and needs to rest.

dialogues.speaker: BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Ellen realizes that there is no way she can untie herself But slowly, she manages to loosen one of the bed planks  that she is tied to - bit by tedious bit.

dialogues.speaker: IN FRONT OF THE HOUSE / ENTRANCE AREA
dialogues.text: Lindner peeks inside the house past Martin.  He casually  asks:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, what's wrong with her? Martin is still playing around with the hammer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just nerves.  You know, the  move and all that... Lindner realizes that it's no use asking further.  He han over the picture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, then.  Would you please  give this to her for me?  Tell  her, I'd like to talk to her  when she's feeling better.  And  tell her I don't want to run  away anymore.  She'll  understand what I mean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, I'll tell her. The old policeman walks to his car and climbs inside. Martin smiles and waves him good-bye.

dialogues.speaker: BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Ellen has finally made it:  She manages to disconnect the plank. She quickly tears the gag out of her mouth and yells as  loud as she can:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (screams)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Help!  Help, I'm in here!  Help  me! She listens if anyone heard her calling. It's useless.  Lindner has already started his car, and  drives off.  The sound of his car engine fades away in th distance. Ellen is desperate.

dialogues.speaker: ENTRANCE AREA
dialogues.text: Martin heard Ellen's calling.  He grins self-consciously  and locks the house door.  Then, he reaches for a board  leaning against the wall.  He takes a nail out of his  pocket and starts to nail the door shut.

dialogues.speaker: LINDNER'S CAR / COUNTRY ROAD
dialogues.text: Karl Lindner is driving towards Goldmoor.  He is lost in  thought.  Something about the whole situation seemed  strange to him, but he can't put his finger on it. He brakes and looks back toward the house once more (a  moment of hope for Ellen). But then, he shakes his head and steps on the gas pedal  again. The car drives off into the distance.

dialogues.speaker: BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Ellen gets rid of the rest of her ropes, immediately jump up and races to the door. She checks the door: it's locked.  She peeks through the  keyhole. The key is sticking in the opposite side of the door.  We hear Martin hammering downstairs. Ellen has an idea - an ancient trick from childhood days. There is a book on the bedside table.  She tears out a pa and slides it underneath the door, below the door lock. There is a can of nails on the floor which Martin left  behind.  Ellen takes out a nail and uses it to poke aroun in the keyhole. She pushes the key out of the lock.  The key falls to the floor, but it lands next to the sheet of paper. Ellen pulls the book page in under the door - no key!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn. She presses her face flat against the floor and looks  underneath the door crack. There, on the other side, is the key. Suddenly, the hammering stops. Ellen holds her breath...

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: ...The living room windows are all nailed shut.  Martin  prepares to attach the last board.  He reaches into his  pocket - no more nails...!

dialogues.speaker: BEDROOM
dialogues.text: ...The box of nails is lying on the bedroom floor.  Ellen senses that she is running out of time.  She moves faster She pushes the book page under the door again and tries t maneuver it underneath the key...

dialogues.speaker: ENTRANCE AREA
dialogues.text: ...Martin comes out of the living room and heads for the  hallway...

dialogues.speaker: BEDROOM
dialogues.text: ...Ellen has it!  She has managed to get the key on top o the sheet of paper.  Carefully, she pulls it in under the door. She picks it up and pushes it into the lock...

dialogues.speaker: HALLWAY
dialogues.text: ...Martin comes up the stairs.  He heads for the bedroom. When he sees the open door, he stops. He hesitates for a moment, looks around. Then, he carefully approaches the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is somebody trying to run away  here?!  Darling, I'm really  disappointed.  How can we ever  have a trusting marriage if you  keep running away from every  conflict? Martin has reached the bedroom door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You little hardhead, I... At that moment, the door slams into him.  A loud crunch. The wooden door hits him right in the head.  Martin is  knocked to the floor. Ellen comes running out of the bedroom.  She has a wooden plank in her hands.  She wants to make sure that the job done right and clobbers Martin until he stops moving. Then, she sprints to the staircase and runs down the step

dialogues.speaker: ENTRANCE AREA
dialogues.text: Ellen runs to the barricaded house door.  She shakes at t boards, but they are down tight.  No matter how hard Elle tries, it's impossible for her to loosen them. Horrified, she searches for another way out.  She runs to the living room door and looks inside the room...:

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: ...All of the windows are barricaded.  There is no chance to escape!

dialogues.speaker: HALLWAY
dialogues.text: Martin regains conscience.  His head is wounded and  bleeding.  He scrambles to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No matter what you do, Ellen...   you don't stand a chance.   We're not leaving this place  anymore...

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Ellen looks around, helpless.  We hear Martin's voice  coming from upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... not today.  Not tomorrow.   Never again! She discovers the remote control for the TV.  And gets an idea.  She grabs it and runs out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: KITCHEN
dialogues.text: Ellen flees into the kitchen.  The windows are all nailed shut here, too.  Ellen's heart is beating up to her neck. She jerks open a drawer and takes out a big kitchen knife We hear Martin's footsteps coming down the staircase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's like you always wanted.   Us together.  We'll make it  through anything, no matter how  rotten the situation is. Ellen squats next to the door frame.

dialogues.speaker: ENTRANCE AREA
dialogues.text: Martin is walking down the last couple of steps.  Out of  the corner of his eyes, he notices the open kitchen door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you ever wondered why it  hasn't been working out between  us since it all happened?  I've  asked myself that question.   And you know what the answer to  that is?  It was never real.   All just a big lie. While he speaks, Martin slowly moves toward the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: KITCHEN
dialogues.text: Martin has almost reached the kitchen. Quivering, Ellen pushes a button on the remote control...

dialogues.speaker: ENTRANCE AREA
dialogues.text: ...and the television jumps on in the living room, behind Martin.  The loud NOISE startles him; he spins around. Martin smiles and taps the hammer in the palm of his hand Then, he heads towards the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you loved, was something  totally different.  The  successful author, Martin  Straub.  "Mr. Cherry-red Tears"  - you married a goddamned book. Martin disappears in the living room.

dialogues.speaker: KITCHEN
dialogues.text: Ellen sees her chance, and takes it.  She runs out of the kitchen...

dialogues.speaker: ENTRANCE AREA
dialogues.text: ...and up the stairs. Martin sprints out of the living room.  He is after her.

dialogues.speaker: HALLWAY
dialogues.text: Ellen runs into the study.  Martin is right on her heels.

dialogues.speaker: STUDY
dialogues.text: ...Ellen slams the door shut behind her and locks it.  Sh reaches for the telephone next to the computer.

dialogues.speaker: LINDNER'S BEDROOM
dialogues.text: The lights are off in Lindner's bedroom. Karl is lying in bed with his eyes open, staring at the  ceiling.  His wife notices it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You went to see the Straubs'  today, didn't you? Lindner doesn't answer.  The look in his eyes says it all

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you have something on  your mind.  What is it? He hesitates.  Sighs.  Finally, he says it:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it's starting again.   You know... there was something  peculiar.  If only I knew...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peculiar?  You mean, like back  then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, something was... Suddenly, it hits him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My God, the hammer! He jumps out of bed and into his clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hammer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How could I fail to notice  that! - I have to go... He hesitates, looks back at his wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, honey. It is hard for Mrs. Lindner to let her husband go.  But s understands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead.  I know you have to  do this.

dialogues.speaker: STUDY
dialogues.text: Ellen dials the emergency number for the police and races to the window.  She looks down - it's quite a ways down,  and at the bottom, hard stone pavement. The phone RINGS at the other end of the line. Martin rumbles against the door to the study.  He is tryi to get inside.

dialogues.speaker: HALLWAY
dialogues.text: Martin is standing in front of the closed door to the  study, shaking the door handle.  He listens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on...

dialogues.speaker: STUDY
dialogues.text: Ellen still hasn't gotten through to the police.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... I know what you're up to.   You don't think that's going to  work, do you? Ellen desperately looks around the room, searching for a  way out.  She catches sight of the activated computer.   There is a text flickering on the slightly demolished  monitor. Finally, someone answers the phone at the police station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Police headquarters, Webber... Ellen excitedly speaks into the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ellen Straub here.  You have to  help me...

dialogues.speaker: HALLWAY / ENTRANCE AREA
dialogues.text: Martin runs down the stairs to the entrance area.  He hea straight for the distributor box next to the cellar door. One well-aimed blow, and the gray telephone box is  demolished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... please come right away!  My  address is... CLICK!  The conversation is cut off.  The line is dead. But Ellen hardly notices it anymore.  Her eyes are glued the monitor.  Something about it has drawn her full  attention. Her name is written on the monitor screen!  Ellen begins read in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reads)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Ellen woke up from the sound  of the door.  She barely  managed to raise her head in  order to see who the visitor  might be.  His back turned to  Ellen, the man pulled a  wheelchair into the hospital  room.  When he turned around,  she recognized him with horror:  Martin!" Ellen's eyes grow wider with every word she reads.  The  text abruptly stops here. Martin must have known everything!  Her whole story,  everything that happened to her, is described in his new  novel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell... From outside, we hear Martin's voice loud and clear.  He  finishes her sentence for her:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...is going on here? Before Ellen has a chance to give the situation a thought the door breaks open.  The door frame splinters.  Martin  simply kicked the door in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The final chapter will finish  tonight.  I bet you can't wait  to find out how the story ends! Ellen grabs the knife and backs away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My God, Martin.  I don't  understand all this.  How is it  possible? Slowly and threateningly, Martin comes closer.  In his  hands, the hammer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you like my new book?  A  real page-turner, isn't it?  I  can just see the critics:   Martin Straub is back!  And  better than ever. Ellen is backed up against the wall.  She raises the knif against him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay where you are!  Not one  step closer! Martin isn't fazed that easily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You still don't understand, do  you?  Today is the last day.   Your day, Ellen. With this, he jumps up to her, quick as lightning.  He  grabs the knife by the blade and twists it out of Ellen's hand - without the slightest feeling of pain. He firmly pulls Ellen towards the door.  They pass by the desk with the computer.  Ellen sees the electric cord for the computer on the floor. With a swift move of her foot, she tears at the cable,  pulling the computer off of the desk.  It falls to the  floor. Martin screams in rage.  For a second, he is distracted. Ellen takes the opportunity to tear herself loose.

dialogues.speaker: HALLWAY / ENTRANCE AREA
dialogues.text: Terrified, Ellen races down the stairs.  She is looking f a way out. Martin is close on her heels.  In the entrance hall, he  gets hold of her. But Ellen manages to break loose again.  But doing so, sh slips.  Falls. And trips through the open cellar door...

dialogues.speaker: CELLAR
dialogues.text: ... down the stairs. Ellen crash-lands in brackish, brown water.  The cellar i flooded ankle-deep with swamp water.  It is seeping in  through the crevices in the walls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The moor... Martin walks up to her, threateningly.  Ellen scrambles t her feet.  She is hurt.  But Martin walks past her and  steps into the center of the dark cellar. Ellen glances back at the cellar door which is still open Suddenly, an invisible force slams it shut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you, there is no way  out.  He won't let you go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'HE'?  Whom do you mean- Instead of answering, he gently puts his finger on her  mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shh.  Don't you hear that? She looks around. Then she hears it:  The room is filled with quiet WHISPER growing louder and louder - countless voices - the voices of children!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's important - he knows the  last chapter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your book - that's why you were  always in the cellar! Just then, a figure steps out of the darkness.  It is the little son Thomas.  Although he does not move his lips, h seems to be the source of the whispers. He stands next to Martin, who lays his arm around the boy shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now look at this young man:  He  supports me in what I do -  quite the opposite of you. Terrified, Ellen stares at Thomas.  She watches a thin  strand of mud flow out of the boy's shoulder, and - again the laws of gravity - it crawls up over Martin's hand.   Martin does not seem to notice it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, Tommi wants me to  become the man I used to be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs bitterly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...So he's dictating you a new  bestseller?  Whatever that is,  it's not our son. Martin leans down to the child's figure and brings his ea close to Thomas' mouth.  The boy seems to be whispering  something in his ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sharply)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin, don't you understand?   Tommi is dead!  This... it  knows our weaknesses and it's  using them to bring us apart! Martin stays leaned down to Thomas and listens.  He throw a stealthy glance at Ellen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid he doesn't like you  very much. Martin smiles triumphantly.  He reaches into the water an pulls out a metal pipe. He threateningly moves closer to Ellen.  She backs away,  until she finds herself backed up against the wall. Ellen looks around - there is no where to run.  But she  tries anyway.  She wants to make a run for it. But Martin is faster.  He grabs hold of her.  Ellen slips and lands in the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've played this game long  enough. He mercilessly pushes Ellen's head under water.  She trie to put up a fight, but she doesn't stand a chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How sad.  Drowned, like all the  others.  But that's the way  it's got to be in a real horror  novel.  I know what you're  thinking:  No happy end - it'll  never sell.  But to hell with  commerce! Ellen manages to fight her way above the water's surface. She gasps for air.  Her eyes catch sight of the old shelf crammed full with all sorts of junk, standing within reac of her feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's lying, don't you see?   This is all an illusion.  It  lied to us and to all of those  who were here before us... Martin's eyes are beaming with hate.  He does not notice  Ellen kicking for the shelf.  It slightly tips forward,  then back against the wall again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell you what really was  an illusion:  Romantic family  life, by the side of your  successful author.  Sorry if I  wasn't able to live up to your  high expectations, princess. Ellen tries to get through to whatever is left of Martin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wasn't your fault, you hear! Ellen gets another good kick against the shelf - it tips  over and collapses over Martin's head.  Ellen grabs the  chance to free herself. Martin furiously thrusts the shelf aside.  There is an ug wound on his forehead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tommi is dead, you hear! But you and me, we're alive. Again, Ellen is backed up against the wall.  Martin steps up to her.  He is still holding the metal pipe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be quiet. Suddenly, he strikes her with the pipe.  He grabs Ellen b the throat and pushes her against the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you, Martin! For a short moment, something seems to break inside of  Martin.  But then, he tightens his grip on her neck again Ellen is dazed, but she is not afraid any more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then kill me, because... "With  you, my life began and with you  shall it end..." All of a sudden, some of Martin's strength seems to fail. His look freezes.  A single BLACK TEAR runs out of the  corner of his eye. Ellen grabs the metal pipe and shoves Martin away. She jumps over to Thomas...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you!  Don't let a lie  come between us!  Look at this! ...and slashes the pipe at him. The metal penetrates the figure's "body" and destroys the illusion:  The facade of the little boy dissipates into  mud. For a second, Ellen believes to have seen the hideous  figure of a swamp corpse, but the creature instantly melt into the muddy water covering the cellar floor. At this very instant, a loud roll of thunder echoes  throughout the house. Martin abruptly loses all of his strength.  More and more liquid begins to flow out of his eyes.  The strands of mu slither down his body like countless snakes and vanish in the swamp water.  The house begins to quake.  More and more mud seeps in  through the cracks.  The cellar slowly floods.  The walls quiver. Ellen runs to the door:  It is shut tight - there is no w out. The moor is rising.  Ellen grabs Martin, who is still  unconscious and about to drown.  She tries to wake him up

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin!  We have to get out of  here! There is a sudden noise.  Ellen jumps. Something has started to move in the back corner of the  cellar:  A dark something arcs out of the water for a sho moment.  It isn't over, yet!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My God... She vigorously tries to wake Martin, but he does not reac The "thing" is coming closer.  It languidly rolls forward Its shape remains hidden underneath the water's surface. Ellen feverishly searches for a way out.  She notices the small cellar hatch. The house quakes more violently; dust flakes down from th ceiling.  Ellen realizes that the entire house is slowly  sinking into the ground.  And at the same time, the moor rising dangerously high. She grabs Martin by the shoulders.  With all of her  strength, she somehow manages to pull him up onto a pile crates below the cellar hatch. The black thing is coming closer.  It rises up out of the moor. Ellen tries to heave Martin outside through the hatch - b she is not strong enough.  Still, she puts up a desperate fight against the odds. The already small opening of the hatch is growing smaller and smaller:  The tremendous foundations of the house are sinking deeper and deeper into the ground. Suddenly, a hand reaches in through the hatch and grabs a hold of Martin. Ellen starts.  She looks outside.  It's Lindner!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hurry, we don't have much time!   Lift him up higher! Ellen pushes Martin a little bit higher.  Behind her, an  amorphous, black mass is rising up out of the swamp water Numerous strands of mud branch out of it and begin to gro for Ellen. One of the "tentacles" wraps itself around Ellen's foot. Ellen notices it, but can't do anything about it. With one strong jerk, Lindner tugs Martin out of the  cellar. At the same time, Ellen loses hold on the crate.  She is  torn downward and disappears under water. Lindner sticks his head in through the hatch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouts)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ellen! A brief moment of hesitation - then the old policeman  determinedly climbs down into the cellar.  By now, the mo has risen almost to his waist. Lindner wades through the thick liquid.  The surface is  smooth - no sign of Ellen. Then, she suddenly dives back up, gasping for air. Lindner immediately grabs her arm and helps her toward th hatch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's right behind me. Lindner keeps calm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry.  It only has power  over us if we run away. He helps Ellen up onto the crates.  Carefully, she climbs out through the hatch.  She hears Tommi's voice behind he

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mommy... She is tempted to look back.  But Lindner stops her from  doing it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  Don't look back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mommy... The hatch, the last possible exit into freedom, is slowly shrinking to a narrow slit. Ellen reaches out her hand to Lindner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come!  Quick! Lindner climbs onto the crates.   Again, the house quakes.  Single bricks break out of the  walls and ceiling. Ellen's curiosity wins over reason.  She takes a last loo into the cellar. There - in the dark back corner of the cellar - she sees  shriveled figures with hollow eyes, watching the two of  them in silence.  Swamp corpses. Lindner notices her horror, but still remains calm.  He  starts to climb out through the window hatch.

dialogues.speaker: IN FRONT OF THE HOUSE
dialogues.text: Once Lindner is safely outside, Ellen immediately rushes  over to Martin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin! Martin seems to be regaining conscience.  He opens his  eyes.   Ellen wants to say something, but the thunder in the  background suddenly swells up to an infernal noise. Walls collapse, bricks and rubble crash down - the entire house is swallowed by the depths of the moor. The three watch with open-mouthed horror. Then, silence. Ellen leans over to her husband. Martin is still totally worn out.  He moans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smog... Ellen musters him, confused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a yearning for... smog,  cars and many, many people... A real dirty... big city.   What do you think? Ellen gently strokes his cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're back. Martin's eyes are still glued to the spot where the house used to be.  He is still a bit disoriented.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did you get me out of  there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't have made it by  myself. She looks at Lindner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were right:  You can never  run away from the past.   Especially if it scares you. Ellen nods her head. Then, she turns back to Martin.  They look at each other  for a long moment.  Then, she puts her arms around him an kisses him.  It's all over now. There's something else Ellen wants to say to Lindner.  Bu when she turns around, she finds that he's already walked bit away:  He is going to his car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Lindner! The old policeman stops by his car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. Lindner smiles.  Then, he steps into his car and drives  away. Ellen helps Martin to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you walk? Martin is in pain, but brave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No problem. He takes a step, but then he flinches with pain.  The  movement hurt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For God's sake, what happened  to me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't remember? Martin shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a long story. Arm in arm, the two of them stagger to their car which is parked next to the entrance gate, the last remnant of the house. They get into the car and drive off. The car slowly vanishes in the distance, leaving behind t vast, swampy landscape where there was once a house.

dialogues.speaker: APARTMENT HOUSE IN THE CITY
dialogues.text: A beautiful old building, located by a park in the city. Ellen and Martin live in the penthouse. Text chart: "1 year later"

dialogues.speaker: APARTMENT
dialogues.text: Ellen is standing by the window, looking over the small  city park.  She looks happy. Martin joins her at the window and hugs her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a sight:  A few trees, a  couple of ducks in the pond.   That's all the nature I need. Ellen laughs.  They are about to kiss, when suddenly the  doorbell RINGS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you expecting company? Martin shrugs his shoulders and walks to the door.  He  opens it to Paul and Claudia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Surprise! Paul is carrying a package under his arm.  He walks  straight past Martin, to Ellen.  Martin and Claudia follo him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This baby is a dream come true,  I tell ya!  The third edition  within one year!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow! - Considering how it all  came about... Paul tears open the box.  It contains several copies of  "You have 7 Days to Live".  Above the title, it reads:  Ellen and Martin Straub!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You two are one hell of a team!   And as far as I'm concerned:   In case you plan on moving back  to the countryside, I'll be  glad to lend a hand. Martin and Ellen trade looks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you already told him about  our idea for the new novel?  Paul can't wait to find out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?  What's it about? Ellen grins ambiguously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's about this publisher who  constantly gets on his authors'  nerves. Martin plays the ball back to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...until one day, he goes too  far and the two of them get  really mad...

dialogues.speaker: APARTMENT HOUSE IN THE CITY
dialogues.text: We see the four of them standing behind the large window Ellen and Martin's apartment.  The camera pans farther an farther away from them, over the park. They keep the joke running:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and we mean: really mad! The voices slowly fade with the camera's growing distance

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, okay, I get the message!   I was only trying to make a  suggestion, you know. The camera travels further away... over the big city and  it's ever-busy activities.
